metadata.case_name: M. Meyyappa Chettiyar v. Income Tax Officer
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 1060-1064 of 1965 and Civil Appeals Nos. 1103-1107 of 1966

facts.text: In 1940, Meyyappa I, Alagammal his wife, and minor sons Chokalingam and Meyyappa II formed a Hindu Undivided Family trading as M.S.M.M in money lending, rubber plantations, and real estates in Malaya, Burma, and India.
Property of the HUF divided on February 22, 1940 between three male members; Meyyappa I allotted Rangoon and Karaikudi businesses, three rubber estates in Malaya, and some houses.
After partition, Meyyappa I continued management on behalf of himself and minors of all properties and businesses in name M.S.M.M; houses and rubber estates entered in books of M.M. Ipoh.
Alagammal gave birth to son Chettiappa in December 1941; Meyyappa I and Chettiappa constituted Hindu coparcenary owning allotted properties.

Deed of partition executed December 30, 1949 between Meyyappa I and Chokalingam (now major) re businesses in M.S.M.M name; thereafter partnership between Meyyappa I (for self and minor Chettiappa), Chokalingam; Meyyappa II admitted to benefits.

Partition effected April 13, 1950 between Meyyappa I and minor Chettiappa by book entries in M.M. Ipoh; properties held equally, continued management by M.S.M.M firm to benefit of which Chettiappa admitted; deed executed May 28, 1953 by Meyyappa I and Alagammal as guardian.
In 1951, Meyyappa I acceded to Chokalingam's demand on behalf of M.S.M.M firm for half share in M.M. Ipoh properties; no division by metes and bounds, management continued with M.S.M.M firm.
Meyyappa I assessed under Income-tax Act 1922 individually or as karta till assessment year 1953-54 re income from M.M. Ipoh properties.
Income-tax Officer, Karaikudi issued notices u/s 34 for 1951-52 to 1953-54 and u/s 22 for 1954-55 to 1956-57 assessing income of association of persons M.M. Ipoh.
ITO rejected contentions, assessed 1951-52 as AOP by Meyyappa I and Chettiappa; 1952-53 to 1955-57 as AOP by Meyyappa I, M.S.M.M firm, Chettiappa.
Appeals to AAC: confirmed ITO orders subject to modification that income from houses assessed u/s 9 individually, not collectively.
Tribunal referred u/s 66 question: Whether assessments on AOP for 1951-52 to 1956-57 valid? Declined other questions incl whether materials to hold assessee principal officer of M.M. Ipoh.
Madras HC on April 3, 1961: 1951-52 no AOP; 1952-53 to 1956-57 AOP by Meyyappa I, M.S.M.M firm, minor Chettiappa; Meyyappa I principal officer; answered accordingly.
November 21, 1961: Writ petitions u/Art 226 in Madras HC for prohibition re demands on M.M. Ipoh AOP; urged s.3 arbitrary violating Art 14.
Madras HC on November 29, 1963 rejected writs.
Special leave appeals to SC: 1060-1064/1965 from tax reference; 1103-1107/1966 from writs.

legal_issues.text: Whether assessments on M.M. Ipoh as association of persons for 1951-52 to 1956-57 valid?
Whether materials to hold assessee as principal officer of M.M. Ipoh AOP?
Whether s.3 Income-tax Act invests ITO with arbitrary power violating Art 14?
Whether AOP existed given minor Chettiappa's involvement and lack of assent?

petitioner_arguments.text: No association of persons existed, esp 1951-52; minor Chettiappa could not form AOP; no assent by guardian.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Income-tax Act s.3; definition of person

petitioner_arguments.text: S.3 confers arbitrary unfettered discretion on ITO to assess AOP collectively or members individually, violating Art 14.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Constitution Art 14; Suraj Mall Mohta precedent

petitioner_arguments.text: No materials/evidence to hold Meyyappa I as principal officer; no prior notice or enquiry.
Repeal of s.23A(1) removed guidance, making discretion unfettered.

respondent_arguments.text: AOP formed by Meyyappa I, M.S.M.M firm, Chettiappa from 1952-53; common management, purpose to earn income; guardian assented.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Income-tax Act s.3; precedents like Indira Balkrishna

respondent_arguments.text: S.3 guided by Act's scheme to prevent tax evasion; quasi-judicial, appealable; not arbitrary.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Income-tax Act s.3; precedents Ram Krishna Dalmia, Jyoti Pershad, Kanpur Coal Syndicate

respondent_arguments.text: Meyyappa I principal officer; notices served, returns filed, no objection earlier.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Income-tax Act s.2(12), s.43 analogy; Nawal Kishore precedent

court_reasoning.text: S.3 not violative of Art 14; guidance from Act's policy to prevent evasion, quasi-judicial exercise, appealable; analogous to unregistered firms.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty to administer for public revenue constitutes adequate principle.

court_reasoning.text: AOP existed 1952-53 onwards: common management/selling agency by M.S.M.M firm post-share adjustment; Alagammal assented as guardian; minor can be member; different from 1951-52.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Abundant material proves joint enterprise for income.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal finding of fact on assent and AOP not disturbable; not res judicata across years.
Meyyappa I principal officer: notices served, returns filed by him, assessment order finds so; no prior declaration needed pre-assessment.

holdings.text: S.3 valid, does not violate Art 14.
Assessments as AOP valid for 1952-53 to 1956-57.
Meyyappa I rightly treated as principal officer.

precedents_cited.case_name: Suraj Mall Mohta Co. v. A. V. Visvanatha Sastri
precedents_cited.relevance: Discriminatory procedure under different Act; not applicable here as same procedure.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Guidance for discretion need not be express; from policy/scheme.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jyoti Pershad v. Administrator for Union Territory of Delhi
precedents_cited.relevance: Policy from preamble, circumstances, other provisions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. v. Kanpur Coal Syndicate
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal power to direct individual assessment.
Minor does not affect AOP existence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Indira Balkrishna
precedents_cited.relevance: AOP requires common purpose/action for income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Nawal Kishore Kharaiti Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: No prior order needed before notice to agent/principal officer.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Assessment of AOP collectively or individually; notices; principal officer; prevents evasion.

outcome.summary: Both sets of appeals dismissed; upheld HC orders validating assessments on AOP M.M. Ipoh for 1952-53 to 1956-57, s.3 constitutional, Meyyappa I principal officer; writs rejected.
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs; one hearing fee each group.

key_quotes.text: The duty of the Income-tax Officer is to administer the provisions of the Act in the interests of public revenue, and to prevent evasion or escapement of tax legitimately due to the State.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: an association of persons must be one in which two or more persons join in a common purpose or common action, and as the words occur in a section which imposes a tax on income, the association must be one the object of which is to produce income.
key_quotes.speaker: court
